studyNotes:
53-yr, 4-yr, 10-yr, and 9-yr-long bimonthly time series of oxygen isotopes (d18O), Sr/Ca, and U/Ca from 4.4 ka and 4.9 ka corals in Okinawa, Japan
       Provided Keywords: mid-Holocene, coral, d18O, Sr/Ca, U/Ca, EAM, ENSO

author.name: Asami, R., Yoshimura, N., Toriyabe, H., Minei, S., Shinjo, R., Hogo, C., Sakamaki, T., and Fujita, K.

publication.title: High-Resolution Evidence for Middle Holocene East Asian Winter and Summer Monsoon Variations: Snapshots of Fossil Coral Records
publication.citation: Asami, R., Yoshimura, N., Toriyabe, H., Minei, S., Shinjo, R., Hogo, C., Sakamaki, T., and Fujita, K. 2020. High-Resolution Evidence for Middle Holocene East Asian Winter and Summer Monsoon Variations: Snapshots of Fossil Coral Records. Geophysical Research Letters, 47, e2020GL088509. doi: 10.1029/2020GL088509
publication.abstract: We first generated 53-yr, 4-yr, 10-yr, and 9-yr-long bimonthly time series of oxygen isotopes (d18O), Sr/Ca, and U/Ca from 4.4 and 4.9 ka corals in Okinawa, Japan. Results indicate that the mid-Holocene sea surface temperature (SST) and seawater d18O were <1 °C lower and 0.1-0.2 ‰ higher than today. Spectral analyses of reconstructed SST and seawater d18O time series revealed East Asia monsoon (EAM) and El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) variations. Moreover, the latter had a dominant component of decade-scale hydrologic variations. The Sr/Ca and U/Ca variations with removal of the ENSO component showed larger fluctuations by ~2 °C in winter and ~0.6 °C in summer at 4.4 ka relative to today, demonstrating (slightly) greater influences of the EAM variation on the northwestern subtropical Pacific in winter (summer) at that time, which are probably caused by enhancement of the EAM intensity and/or a southward migration of the latitudinal circulation.

paleoData.dataTableNotes: The respective 14C ages of the top and bottom of the NH-2-C1 sample are 4367 ± 141 and 4425 ± 145 cal. yr BP. The 14C ages of the NH-2-C2 sample is 4917 ± 120 cal. yr BP. Core lengths: 70cm (NH-2-C1), 26cm (NH-2-C2)
